'''Ray C. Anderson''' (July 28, 1934 – August 8, 2011)<ref name=wapo>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/ray-anderson-greenest-ceo-in-america-dies-at-77/2011/08/10/gIQAGoTU7I_story.html |title= Ray Anderson, ‘greenest CEO in America,’ dies at 77 |work= Washington Post |first= Emily |last= Langer |date= August 10, 2011}}</ref> was founder and chairman of [[Interface Inc.]], one of the world's largest [[manufacturing|manufacturers]] of modular carpet for commercial and residential applications and a leading producer of commercial broadloom and commercial fabrics. He was "known in [[environmental movement|environmental]] circles for his advanced and [[progressivism|progressive]] stance on industrial ecology and sustainability."<sup>[[#External links|1]]</sup>
Anderson died on August 8, 2011, twenty months after being diagnosed with cancer.<ref name=nyt>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/11/business/ray-anderson-a-carpet-innovator-dies-at-77.html |title= Ray Anderson, Businessman Turned Environmentalist, Dies at 77 |work= New York Times |first= Paul |last= Vitello |date= August 10, 2011}}</ref><ref name=sp>{{cite web |url= http://www.smartplanet.com/blog/business-brains/rip-sustainability-pioneer-ray-anderson/17871 |title= RIP, sustainability pioneer Ray Anderson |work= Smart Planet |date=August 10, 2011}}</ref> On July 28, 2012, Anderson’s family re-launched the Ray C. Anderson Foundation.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.raycandersonfoundation.org/articles/54-test-article |title= Foundation launches on birthday of Ray C. Anderson; Refocuses on funding sustainability research projects |publisher= Ray C. Anderson Foundation |date= July 28, 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120811032701/http://www.raycandersonfoundation.org/articles/54-test-article |archivedate= August 11, 2012 |df= mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.greenbiz.com/blog/2012/07/29/new-foundation-honor-ray-andersons-legacy |title= A New Foundation to Honor Ray Anderson’s Legacy |work= GreenBiz |first= Joel |last= Makower |date= July 31, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.greenbiz.com/blog/2012/08/06/why-aren%E2%80%99t-there-more-ray-andersons |title= Why Aren’t There More Ray Andersons? |work= GreenBiz |first= Joel |last= Makower |date= August 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://lauraseydel.com/2012/08/remembering-a-visionary-the-ray-c-anderson-foundation/ |title= Remembering a Visionary—The Ray C Anderson Foundation |publisher= Laura Turner Seydel |date= August 9, 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131224113309/http://lauraseydel.com/2012/08/remembering-a-visionary-the-ray-c-anderson-foundation/ |archivedate= December 24, 2013 |df= mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.raycandersonfoundation.org/articles/115- |title= Foundation website to advance the legacy of Ray C. Anderson (1934-2011), America's Greenest CEO |publisher= Ray C. Anderson Foundation |date= August 8, 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120814040246/http://www.raycandersonfoundation.org/articles/115- |archivedate= August 14, 2012 |df= mdy-all }}</ref> with a new purpose.
Originally created to fund Ray Anderson’s personal philanthropic giving, family members announced the rebirth and refocus of the Foundation on Anderson’s birthday, nearly one year after his 2011 death. The purpose of the Ray C. Anderson Foundation is to perpetuate shared values and continue the legacy that Anderson left behind. The Ray C. Anderson Foundation is a not-for-profit 501(c)3 organization whose mission is to promote and advance the concepts of sustainable production and consumption.
==Life and career==
Anderson was an honors graduate of the [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] in the school of industrial and systems engineering in 1956.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.gatech.edu/newsroom/release.html?nid=69252 |title= ISyE Alumnus and Interface Chairman Ray Anderson Dies |publisher= Georgia Tech |date= August 9, 2011}}</ref> He learned the carpet trade through more than 14 years at [[Milliken & Company|Deering, Milliken & Company]] and Callaway Mills.
Anderson founded Interface in 1973 to produce the first free-lay carpet tiles in America.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.interfaceglobal.com/Company/History.aspx |title= Company History |publisher= Interface, Inc}}</ref> Interface is one of the world’s largest producers of modular commercial floorcoverings, with sales in 110 countries and manufacturing facilities on four continents.<ref>[http://www.ecdm.gatech.edu/content/interface-inc Georgia Tech Interface]</ref>
==Environmental focus== Anderson first turned his focus toward the environment in 1994 when he read ''The Ecology of Commerce'' by [[Paul Hawken]],<ref name=nyt /> and also ''[[Ishmael (novel)|Ishmael]]'' by [[Daniel Quinn]], seeking inspiration for a speech to an internal task force on the company’s environmental vision. Hawken argues that the [[industrialisation|industrial system]] is destroying the planet and only industry leaders are powerful enough to stop it.
In 2009, Anderson estimated that Interface was more than halfway towards the vision of “Mission Zero,”<ref>[http://www.grist.org/article/2009-10-19-ray-anderson-sustainability-interview-book “Green-biz pioneer Ray Anderson says sustainability literally pays for itself,”] Grist</ref> the company’s promise to eliminate any negative impact it may have on the environment by the year 2020 through the redesign of processes and products, the pioneering of new technologies, and efforts to reduce or eliminate waste and harmful emissions while increasing the use of renewable materials and sources of energy.<ref name=guardian>[https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/blog/ray-anderson-dies-interface-john-elkington-tribute “Ray Anderson, sustainable business pioneer, dies aged 77,”] The Guardian</ref><ref>[http://www.interfaceglobal.com/Newsroom/Ecometrics.aspx Interface’s Mission Zero Progress] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903182722/http://www.interfaceglobal.com/Newsroom/Ecometrics.aspx |date=September 3, 2011 }}</ref>
Anderson chronicled the Mission Zero journey in two books, ''Mid-Course Correction: Toward a Sustainable Enterprise: The Interface Model'' (1998) and ''Confessions of a Radical Industrialist: Profits, People, Purpose: Doing Business by Respecting the Earth'' (2009).<ref>{{YouTube|M3qFL3kRDDE|Ray Anderson Interview}}</ref><ref>[http://www.greenlivingonline.com/article/confessions-radical-industrialist “Confessions of a Radical Industrialist,”] Green Living</ref> The latter was released in paperback as ''Business Lessons from a Radical Industrialist'' in 2011.
==Recognition and awards== Anderson was featured several documentaries and films, such as ''[[The Corporation (2003 film)|The Corporation]]'', (2004 Canadian documentary); ''[[The 11th Hour (2007 film)|The 11th Hour]]'' (2007 [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] film); ''[[I Am (2011 film)|I Am]]'' (2011 [[Tom Shadyac]] documentary); ''[[Big Ideas for a Small Planet]]'' ([[Sundance Channel (United States)|Sundance Channel]] series); and others.
The Interface story is the focus of the documentary film “So Right, So Smart” (2009).<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090217191844/http://magicwig.com/WhatWeDo/documentary/index.html Magic Green Pictures, So Right, So Smart]</ref>
Ray served a stint as co-chair of the President’s Council on Sustainable Development during President Clinton’s administration, which led to him co-chairing the Presidential Climate Action Plan in 2008, a team that presented the Obama Administration with a 100-day action plan on climate.<ref name=bio>[http://www.interfaceglobal.com/Company/Leadership-Team/Ray-Watch/Meet-Ray.aspx Ray Anderson Biography]</ref> Together, he and Interface funded the creation of the Anderson-Interface Chair in Natural Systems at Georgia Tech, where Associate Professor Valerie Thomas conducts research in [[sustainability]].<ref>[http://greenbuildingchronicle.com/2011/08/07/ray-anderson-awarded-honorary-doctorate-at-georgia-tech/ “Ray Anderson awarded honorary doctorate at Georgia Tech,”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111122213329/http://greenbuildingchronicle.com/2011/08/07/ray-anderson-awarded-honorary-doctorate-at-georgia-tech/ |date=November 22, 2011 }} Green Building Chronicle</ref>
Ray Anderson received a host of accolades throughout his life, including:
* In 2007, he was named one of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''’s Heroes of the Environment.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/specials/2007/article/0,28804,1663317_1663322_1669929,00.html “Heroes of the Environment,”] TIME</ref> * Inaugural Millennium Award from Global Green, presented by Mikhail Gorbachev (1996)<ref>[http://www.globalgreen.org/awards/2 “Past Millennium Award Recipients”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906072530/http://globalgreen.org/awards/2 |date=September 6, 2011 }}</ref> * Recognized by ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine and [[Ernst & Young]], which named him Entrepreneur of the Year in 1996.<ref name=bio /> * The [[American Society of Interior Designers]] Design for Humanity Award (2010)<ref>[http://www.asid.org/NR/rdonlyres/48425334-63FC-46DD-85C1-D25513AA9279/0/ASID_Award_Winners2010.pdf “ASID Announces ASID Awards Winners”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002230651/http://www.asid.org/NR/rdonlyres/48425334-63FC-46DD-85C1-D25513AA9279/0/ASID_Award_Winners2010.pdf |date=October 2, 2011 }}</ref> * Lifetime Achievement Award from GreenLaw (2010) * The inaugural Global Sustainability Prize from the [[University of Kentucky]] Tracy Farmer Institute for Sustainability and the Environment (2010)<ref>[http://www.ca.uky.edu/news/?c=n&d=699 “Research Showcase to celebrate accomplishments in sustainability”]</ref> * River Guardian Award from the [[Upper Chattahoochee Riverkeeper]] (2010)<ref>[http://www.ajc.com/news/atlanta/ray-anderson-to-receive-593859.html “Ray Anderson to receive River Guardian Award,”] Atlanta Journal-Constitution</ref> * Sustainability Award from the Women’s Network for a Sustainable Future (WNSF), the first time the WNSF has honored a businessman (2010)<ref>[http://network.theglasshammer.com/forum/topics/womens-network-for-a “Women's Network for a Sustainable Future - WNSF 7th Annual Award to Ray Anderson,”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330221010/http://network.theglasshammer.com/forum/topics/womens-network-for-a |date=March 30, 2012 }} The Glass Hammer Network</ref> * Pillars of EARTH Sustainable Leadership Awards given by [[EARTH University]] in Costa Rica (2010)<ref>[http://www.globalatlanta.com/cal/event/2223/ “Pillars of EARTH: Sustainable Leadership Awards”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317125027/http://www.globalatlanta.com/cal/event/2223/ |date=March 17, 2012 }}</ref> * Purpose Prize from [[Encore.org]] (2007)<ref>[http://www.encore.org/learn/purpose-prize-winner-0 “Purpose Prize Winner, Environmentalist Ray Anderson Dies at 77”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004223253/http://www.encore.org/learn/purpose-prize-winner-0 |date=October 4, 2011 }}</ref> * [[Auburn University]]’s International Quality of Life Award (2007)<ref>[http://wireeagle.auburn.edu/news/251 “AU Quality of Life Award honors Ray Anderson at United Nations”]</ref> * George and Cynthia Mitchell International Prize for Sustainable Development (2001)<ref name=bio />
Under Anderson’s leadership, Interface was named to CRO magazine’s (formerly Business Ethics magazine) 100 Best Corporate Citizens List for three years.<ref>[http://www.greenlivingguy.com/greenliving/interface-founder-and-chairman-ray-anderson-visionary-entrep.html “Interface founder and chairman Ray Anderson, visionary entrepreneur and champion of the environment,”] Green Living Guy</ref> In 2006, Sustainablebusiness.com named Interface to their SB20 list of Companies Changing the World,<ref>[http://www.sustainablebusiness.com/index.cfm/go/news.feature/id/1468 “The 2007 SB20: World's Top Sustainable Stocks,”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927095113/http://www.sustainablebusiness.com/index.cfm/go/news.feature/id/1468 |date=September 27, 2011 }} SustainableBusiness.com</ref> and in 2006 GlobeScan listed Interface #1 in the world for corporate sustainability.<ref>[http://www.globescan.com/news_archives/tss_release01/ “Companies and Governments Lag NGOs in Driving Sustainability but New Corporate Leaders Emerging, According to Experts,”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927184437/http://www.globescan.com/news_archives/tss_release01/ |date=September 27, 2011 }} The Sustainability Survey</ref>
Anderson was former Board Chair for The Georgia Conservancy and served on the boards of the Ida Cason Callaway Foundation, Rocky Mountain Institute, the David Suzuki Foundation, Emory University Board of Ethics Advisory Council, the ASID Foundation, Worldwatch Institute, and the Arizona State University Global Institute of Sustainability Advisory Board. He was on the Advisory Boards of the Harvard Medical School Center for Health and the Global Environment and the Upper Chattahoochee Riverkeeper.<ref name=bio />
He was awarded 12 honorary doctorates from Northland College (public service), LaGrange College (business), N.C. State University (humane letters), University of Southern Maine (humane letters), The University of the South (civil law), and Colby College (law), [[Kendall College of Art and Design]] (art), Emory University (science), Central College in Pella, Iowa, (humane letters), Chapman University (humane letters), Clarkson University (science), and the Georgia Institute of Technology (philosophy).<ref>[http://www.bizjournals.com/prnewswire/press_releases/2011/08/05/NY48317 “InterfaceFLOR Founder and Chairman Ray Anderson Awarded Honorary Doctorate From Georgia Tech”]</ref>
Anderson’s papers were donated to the [[Georgia Historical Society]] by the Ray C. Anderson Foundation and Interface, Inc. in late 2015. The collection, which includes biographical materials, business records, correspondence, organizational records, photographs, presentations, speeches, writings, travel files, and books, is available at the Georgia Historical Society’s Research Center in Savannah. The online finding aid can be found [http://ghs.galileo.usg.edu/ghs/view?docId=ead/MS%202603-ead.xml;query=;brand=default here].<ref>[http://georgiahistory.com/georgia-historical-society-announces-the-collection-of-environmental-visionary-ray-c-anderson-now-open-for-research/ “Georgia Historical Society Announces the Collection of Environmental Visionary Ray C. Anderson Now Open For Research”] Georgiahistory.com</ref>

{{Infobox court case |name = Re Bristol South-East Parliamentary Election 1961 |court = [[Election court]] |image = Royal Coat of Arms of the United Kingdom.svg |imagesize = 150px |imagelink = |imagealt = |caption = |full name = |date decided = <!-- {{start date|yyyy|mm|dd|df=}} --> |citations = 3 All ER 354. |ECLI = |transcripts = |judges = Justice Gorman, Justice McNair JJ |number of judges = 2 |decision by = |concurring = |dissenting = |concur/dissent = |prior actions = |appealed from = |appealed to = |subsequent actions = |related actions = [[Peerage Act 1963]] |opinions = |keywords = {{hlist |disclaiming peerages }} |italic title = }} '''''Re Bristol South-East Parliamentary Election''''' ([1961] 3 All ER 354) is a 1961 United Kingdom [[election court]] case brought about by an [[election petition]] by [[Malcolm St Clair (politician)|Malcolm St Clair]] against [[Tony Benn]], the winner of the [[Bristol South East by-election, 1961|1961 Bristol South-East by-election]] where Benn had won the most votes but was disqualified from taking his seat in the [[House of Commons]] as he had inherited a [[hereditary peer]]age as 2nd [[Viscount Stansgate]].<ref name=wiley>{{cite paper|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-2230.1961.tb00672.x/pdf |title=No parity for peers |work=The Modern Law Review |date= |accessdate=2018-05-04}}</ref> Benn argued that as he had not applied for a [[Hereditary peer#Writs of summons|writ of summons]], he was not a member of the [[House of Lords]] and that the voters had the right to choose who they wanted to represent them.<ref name=nlj />
The court made a ruling of undue election because the voters were aware that Benn was legally disqualified from sitting in the House of Commons, their votes had to be counted as being "thrown away" and [[Malcolm St Clair (politician)|Malcolm St Clair]] as the runner-up would take the seat instead.<ref name="lawcom1">{{cite paper|url=http://www.lawcom.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Electoral-Law_Legal-Challenge.pdf |title=Legal challenge to elections |publisher=Law Commission |date= |accessdate=2018-05-04}}</ref>
== Background == Anthony Wedgwood Benn had been elected as the MP for Bristol South East since 1950 as a [[Labour Party (United Kingdom)|Labour Party]] candidate. During that time he was heir to the Viscount Stansgate title held by his father [[William Wedgwood Benn, 1st Viscount Stansgate]], which Benn tried several times to renounce his right to. When his father died in 1961, Benn called the [[Speaker of the House of Commons (United Kingdom)|Speaker of the House of Commons]] to inform him of this. The Speaker told Benn that because he was now legally a peer, he was disqualified from sitting and speaking in the House of Commons.<ref name=pow /> A by-election was called and Benn decided to fight it anyway. The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] candidate, Malcolm St Clair ran several adverts in local papers telling voters that there was no point in voting for Benn as he was disqualified from sitting in the House of Commons as he was a hereditary peer.<ref name=bbc /> Despite this, Benn won the election and went to the door of the House of Commons to take his [[oath of allegiance]]. However the doorkeeper of the House had been told by the Speaker to not allow Benn access, specifically authorising the use of force to prevent him entering,<ref name=pow>{{cite book |first=David |last=Powell | title =Tony Benn: A Political Life | publisher = Bloomsbury Publishing | edition = | year = 2001 |volume=| isbn =0826456995|pages=20-21 }}</ref> because he was not legally allowed in the Commons as a hereditary peer.<ref name=pow />
St Clair issued an election petition against the results stating that Benn could not take his seat as he was disqualified.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/guides/newsid_82000/82135.stm |title=Election petitions |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-08-20 |accessdate=2018-05-04}}</ref> The petition was accepted by the [[Queen's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice of England and Wales]] and the case would be heard by an election court. During the two months preceding the case, Benn along with his sons [[Stephen Benn|Stephen]] and [[Hilary Benn|Hilary]], and his legal advisor [[Michael Zander]] were granted permission by the Speaker to access the [[House of Commons Library]] to help with their case.<ref name=nlj>{{cite web|first=Michael |last=Zander |authorlink=Michael Zander |url=https://www.newlawjournal.co.uk/content/how-lose-title |title=How to lose a title |work=New Law Journal |date= |accessdate=2018-05-04}}{{Subscription required}}</ref>
== Court hearing == Against legal advice of the Labour Party's [[Queen's Counsel]]s, Benn represented himself ''[[Litigant in person|in pro per]]'' during the proceedings.<ref name=nlj /> During his opening address, Benn took 22 hours to make it and took 537 questions while doing so.<ref name=nlj /> Sir Andrew Clark QC, acting as St Clair's barrister argued in his response that a peer upon succession, regardless of whether they had asked for one or not, was entitled to a [[Hereditary peer#Writs of summons|writ of summons]] to the House of Lords which the Crown could not refuse to grant. He argued that merely having that right was grounds for disqualification as being a member of the House of Lords was incompatible with being an MP in the House of Commons.<ref name=nlj />
Benn argued that to expel an elected member of the House of Commons on the grounds that he had the right for a writ of summons, was to punish him for doing something he hadn't done. He cited there was no precedence to punish a hereditary peer for refusing a writ of summons and referenced the [[Garter King of Arms]]'s [[Roll of the Peerage|Register of Lords Spiritual and Temporal]], where there were forty instances in 500 years of peers not claiming their right to a writ.<ref name=nlj /> Since 1955, if a peer did not reply to the [[Lord Chancellor]] in relation to their right, they were deemed to be on a [[leave of absence]] and attendance was not expected.<ref name=nlj />
== Verdict == Justices Gorman and McNair delivered their verdict, which took two hours to read out. During it they praised Benn for “the magnificent way he had presented his case”.<ref name=nlj /> However, they found the election of Benn to be undue, as he had succeeded his father as Viscount Stansgate and thus was disqualified from being elected as a hereditary peer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.paimages.co.uk/image-details/2.18238862 |title=Election Court Hearing – Tony Benn – The Strand, London |publisher=PA Images |date= |accessdate=2018-05-04}}</ref> They stated that a hereditary peerage was "an incorporeal hereditament affixed to your blood and annexed for posterity".<ref name=bbc>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-23447489 |title=Peers' battle to stay in the Commons |publisher=BBC News |date=2013-07-26 |accessdate=2018-05-04}}</ref> They made their judgement in favour of St Clair as despite the voters knowing that Benn was disqualified during the election campaign, their votes were to be treated as being "thrown away" as they had been given notice by St Clair of Benn's ineligibility.<ref>{{cite web|last=Davies |first=Leila |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/node/158678 |title=Letters – Without peerage |work=New Statesman |date=2003-11-10 |accessdate=2018-05-04}}</ref> Benn's attempts to renounce his title were stated as being too technical for voters to have easily understood.<ref name="lawcom1"/> As a result, St Clair was elected in place of Benn.<ref name="lawcom1"/>
== Aftermath == Despite losing the court case, Benn continued to campaign to be able to renounce his peerage. The [[Peerage Act 1963]] was passed which allowed for hereditary peers to disclaim their peerage and surrender their right to sit in the House of Lords.<ref name=bbc /> This act was created partially as a result of Benn's campaign but also because of the Conservative Party wishing for either [[Alec Douglas-Home|Alec Douglas-Home, Earl of Home]] or [[Quintin Hogg, Baron Hailsham of St Marylebone|Quintin Hogg, Viscount Hailsham]] to become Prime Minister and it was considered constitutionally inappropriate for the Prime Minister to sit in the House of Lords.<ref name=bbc /> Benn took the opportunity to disclaim his title 22 minutes after the bill had come into law.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/43072/page/6534 |title=page 6534, Issue 43072 |work=The London Gazette |date=1963-08-02 |accessdate=2018-05-04}}</ref> St Clair, acting pursuant to a promise he made to respect the wishes of the people of his constituency, agreed to take the position of [[Crown Steward and Bailiff of the Manor of Northstead]], an [[office of profit]] under the Crown, in order to disqualify himself from his seat. This forced a by-election which Benn won, allowing him to reclaim his seat in the House of Commons.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bristol/content/articles/2008/04/03/tony_benn_profile_feature.shtml |title=Profile: Tony Benn |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2018-05-04}}</ref>

{{for|the ice hockey player|Richard Desmond (ice hockey)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Richard Desmond | image = Chancellor George Osborne and Richard Desmond.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Richard Desmond (left) with [[George Osborne]] in 2010 | birth_name = Richard Clive Desmond | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1951|12|08}}{{cite web|url=http://web.researcha.com/iccquery/detail/?did=9137253&c=uk |title=Researcha |publisher=Web.researcha.com |accessdate=20 September 2013}} | birth_place = [[Hampstead]], London, England | death_date = | death_place = | residence = {{nowrap|[[Hampstead]], London, England}} | nationality = British | title = {{nowrap|Owner of [[Northern & Shell]]}} | term = since 1974 | occupation = Publisher, businessman, | years_active = since 1972 | television = [[Television X]] (1995–2016){{cite news|last=Plunkett|first=John|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/01/richard-desmond-sells-adult-tv-channels-express-star-television-x|title=Richard Desmond sells his adult TV channels|work=The Guardian|date=1 April 2016|accessdate=2 April 2016}}
[[Red Hot TV (UK)|Red Hot TV]] (2000–2016)
[[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] (2010–2014) | net_worth = {{gain}} [[Pound sterling|£]]2.5 billion{{cite news|title=Sunday Times Rich List|accessdate=30 April 2016|work=Sunday Times, 24 April 2017}} | spouse = {{unbulleted list| {{marriage|Janet Robertson|1983|2010}} | {{marriage|Joy Canfield|2012}} }} | children = 1 daughter, 2 sons | website = {{URL|northernandshell.co.uk/}} }} '''Richard Clive Desmond''' (born 8 December 1951) is a British publisher, businessman and philanthropist. He is the former owner of [[Express Newspapers]] and founder of [[Northern & Shell]], which publishes various celebrity magazines, such as ''[[OK!]]'' and ''[[New!]]'', and British national newspapers ''[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]'' and ''[[Daily Express]]''. Express Newspapers were sold to Reach Plc (formerly Trinity Mirror) for a consideration of £200m of which £74m was invested in the Express newspapers pension scheme until 2027.https://www.theguardian.com/trinity-mirror-buys-express-star Northern & Shell owned Channel 5 before selling it to US broadcaster Viacom for £463m in May 2014.The Guardian, 1 May 2014 https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/may/01/viacom-purchase-channel-5-richard-desmond The company sold its adult television network, Portland, in April 2016 for less than £1m. In 2010, Desmond was ranked the equal-57th richest man in Britain according to ''[[Sunday Times Rich List 2010|The Sunday Times Rich List]]'',{{cite news| url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/specials/rich_list/rich_list_2009/article6139764.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=Richard Desmond | date=26 April 2009 | accessdate=22 May 2010}} with a net worth of £950 million. He was once again listed on [[Sunday Times Rich List 2011|the 2011 ''Sunday Times Rich List'']], with his fortune still at £950 million. In 2014, he was ranked 78th and worth £1.2 billion. In 2016 Forbes estimated his fortune at close to $1.49 billion,{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/richard-desmond/|title=Richard Desmond|website=Forbes|access-date=2016-04-26}} while [[Sunday Times Rich List 2016|the 2016 ''Sunday Times Rich List'']] reported his net worth at £2.25 billion. When [[Sunday Times Rich List 2017|the 2017 ''Sunday Times Rich List'']] was announced, it recorded a rise in his net worth of £250m, to £2.5 billion, making him the 46th richest person in Britain. In 2015, Desmond released his autobiography ''The Real Deal''.The Sunday Times, 21 June 2015 http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/culture/books/non_fiction/article1569500.ece ==Early life== Desmond was born in Hampstead, London, into a [[British Jews|Jewish]] family, the youngest of three children, and grew up in Edgware, in north west London.{{cite news| url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/article6727593.ece | location=London | work=The Times | title=PROFILE Richard Desmond | date=26 July 2009 | first1=Patrick | last1=Hosking | first2=David | last2=Wighton}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thejc.com/35583/richard-desmond-new-tv-bid |title=Richard Desmond in new TV bid |first= |last= |work=BBC |year=2010 |accessdate=15 June 2011}} His father was descended from Latvian Jews, and his mother was of Ukrainian-Jewish descent.{{cite book|author=Richard Desmond|title=The Real Deal: The Autobiography of Britain's Most Controversial Media Mogul|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z6K4BgAAQBAJ|date=18 June 2015|publisher=Random House|isbn=978-1-4735-1854-4}} His father, Cyril, was at one time managing director of cinema advertising company [[Pearl & Dean]]. An ear infection caused the sudden loss of Cyril's hearing and, according to Richard, he used to take him along, when he was no more than three years old, to act as "his ears" in business meetings, where he ostensibly acquired his "first taste of business dealings".[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/richard-desmond-ive-got-so-much-money-its-ridiculous-2006112.html "Richard Desmond: 'I've got so much money it's ridiculous'"] ''The Independent'', 21 June 2010 After Cyril lost a significant amount of family money to gambling, his parents divorced[https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2010/aug/15/tim-adams-profile-richard-desmond "Richard Desmond: Never afraid to Express himself"] ''The Guardian'', 15 August 2010 and 11-year-old Desmond moved with his mother, Millie, into a flat above a garage; he has described his impoverished early adolescence as a time when he was "very fat and very lonely". Desmond was educated at Edgware Junior School and [[Christ's College, Finchley]].Blackhurst, Chris (1 December 2010) [http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/features/1042695/the-mt-interview-richard-desmond/ "The MT Interview: Richard Desmond"]. ''Management Today''. Retrieved 25 June 2015 ==Early business career== Desmond left school at 15 and started working in the classified advertisements section of the [[Thomson Newspapers|Thomson Group]], while playing the drums at gigs after a day's work. After moving to another company, he became sales director of Beat Instrumental Magazine at 18. Desmond owned two record shops by the time he was 21.Alex Benady [http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/news/412585/LARGING-RICHARD-DESMOND/ "Larging It Up With Richard Desmond"], ''Management Today'', 1 October 2003 In the mid-1970s, Desmond combined his interest in music and advertising to found, with [[Ray Hammond]], ''[[International Musician and Recording World]]'', a monthly magazine for musicians, eventually driving out of business long-established publications such as ''[[Beat Instrumental]]''. He was an early pioneer of the international licensing of magazines: ''International Musician'' soon had editions in the US, Australia, Japan, Germany as well as the UK.{{cite news|last=Snoddy| first=Raymond|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/richard-desmond-the-demon-proprietor-of-fleet-street-6159168.html |title=Richard Desmond: The demon proprietor of Fleet Street |work=The Independent| date= 25 October 2004 |accessdate=12 July 2014}} This was followed by the publication of ''Home Organist'', whose editor contributed the old-school motto ''Forti Nihil Difficile'' ("Nothing is difficult for the strong" – it was Disraeli's motto), still used by the Northern & Shell publishing group. Desmond eventually bought out Hammond. In 1982, Northern & Shell began to publish the UK edition of ''[[Penthouse (magazine)|Penthouse]]'', although the licensing deal ended in the 1990s.Terry Kirby [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/from-penthouse-to-penury-the-man-who-would-be-king-of-the-centrefold-100224.html "From 'Penthouse' to penury? The man who would be King of the Centrefold"], ''The Independent'', 14 August 2003 The company soon moved on to publishing a range of adult titles, including ''[[Asian Babes]]'', alongside about 40 other specialist publications, on subjects such as green issues, bicycles, fitness, stamps, cars and cooking. It was the first company to move to the revamped [[London Docklands|Docklands]] and the [[Anne, Princess Royal|Princess Royal]] opened the offices, which were cleaned temporarily of all evidence of ''Penthouse''.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} When the company moved to the Northern & Shell Tower, the [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Duke of Edinburgh]] presided over the ceremonies. Northern & Shell began publication of the celebrity ''[[OK!]]'' magazine as a monthly in 1993, later becoming a weekly in March 1996. It is the largest weekly magazine in the world, with 23 separate editions from the US to Australia to Azerbaijan and with a readership in excess of 31 million. It was originally an imitation of ''[[Hello (magazine)|Hello!]]'' magazine but now outsells its rival. ==New York controversy== Claims of dealings with the New York mafia in the early 1990s emerged in a May 2001 article by [[John Sweeney (journalist)|John Sweeney]] of ''[[The Observer]]''.John Sweeney [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/may/20/uknews.theobserver "Desmond's New York venture"], ''The Observer'', 20 May 2001 Desmond had made a deal in 1991 with Norman Chanes for running advertisements in his adult titles for telephone sex lines run by Chanes mafia associate, [[Richard Martino]] of the [[Gambino crime family]]. The ''[[Village Voice]]'' newspaper asserted in February 2005 that the three men had a meeting in September 1992 at the [[Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts|Four Seasons hotel]] near Hyde Park in London at which Martino accused Desmond of charging high rates for advertisements in magazines which sold no copies.Tom Robbins [http://www.villagevoice.com/news/porn-stars-6404931 "Porn Stars"], ''Village Voice'', 1 February 2005 BBC News reported in 2004 that Desmond did not know the other two men were connected to organised crime,[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3087061.stm "Porn Star!"], BBC News, 9 June 2004 while a spokesman for Northern and Shell said in 2005 that Desmond had never met Martino or had dealings with him.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/feb/17/pressandpublishing.dailyexpress |title=Mafia told Desmond: we'll kill you over porn deal |last1=Teather |first1=David |last2=Milmo|first2=Dan|work=The Guardian |accessdate=26 March 2009 |location=London |date=17 February 2005}} This deal reportedly left the Americans out of pocket, and an October 1992 incident in New York followed in which Desmond's then managing director, Philip Bailey, was violently and sexually assaulted as an explicit threat to Desmond himself. "If your boss sets foot here, he's a dead man", one of the attackers told Bailey according to the article in the ''Village Voice''. Desmond hired James Brown, a convicted criminal, as his bodyguard. Desmond has asserted that this account is false. Desmond continues to regularly visit New York having started OK! USA and grown Northern & Shell in North America since 2004. In February 2005, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that the claim Desmond had received death threats from the New York Gambino mafia family was contained in affidavits from [[FBI]] agents released during Martino's trial relating to the fraudulent use of the telephone lines. Martino pleaded guilty to the charge of trying to extort money from Desmond and Northern and Shell. Desmond has denied the whole episode; he asserted there was no evidence he knew about the fraud perpetrated by Martino. ==Business career (2000–8)== In November 2000, Northern & Shell acquired [[Express Newspapers]] from United News & Media for £125 million,{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3479581.stm | title=Profile: Richard Desmond | author=Jorn Madslien | date=12 February 2006 | publisher=BBC}} enlarging the group to include the ''[[Daily Express|Daily]]'' and ''[[Sunday Express]]'' titles, the ''[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]'' and ''[[Daily Star Sunday]]'' (which Desmond started), and the ''[[Irish Daily Star]]'' (owned jointly with the Irish [[Independent News & Media]] group). The ''Daily'' and ''Sunday Express'' each sell around 700,000 copies per issue.{{cite web | url=http://www.abc.org.uk | title=ABC Circulation Figures | publisher=Audit Bureau of Circulations | accessdate = 4 February 2009}} (December 2008) The ''Daily Star'' was the only national paper to increase sales year on year with an 18% increase from September 2008 to September 2009 {{update inline|date=July 2013}} and circulation figures of around 850,000,[http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/story.asp?sectioncode=1&storycode=44481&c=1 National newspaper circulations] ''Press Gazette'', 16 October 2009 largely due to aggressive pricing policies which significantly undercut competitors such as ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]''. After buying Express Newspapers, Desmond became embroiled in a feud with [[Jonathan Harmsworth, 4th Viscount Rothermere|Viscount Rothermere]], publisher of the ''[[Daily Mail]]'', the rival to the ''Daily Express'', largely derived from stories relating to Rothermere's private life. In February 2004, in a move that some newspapers interpreted[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/desmond-breaks-links-with-porn-as-he-fights-for-telegraph-571818.html "Desmond breaks links with porn as he fights for 'Telegraph'"] ''The Independent'', 2 March 2004 as an attempt to clear and bolster his image[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/3479581.stm "Profile: Richard Desmond"] BBC, 12 February 2004[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/article1101821.ece "Blackout"] ''The Sunday Times'', 23 November 2003 in view of his bid for the ''Daily Telegraph'', Desmond sold the adult magazine business to [[Remnant Media]] for approximately £10 million.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/richard-desmond-the-rebel-entrepreneur-who-went-too-far-561027.html "The rebel entrepreneur who went too far"] ''The Independent'', 24 April 2004 In April 2004, the ''Daily Express'' reverted to supporting the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservatives]], after a period backing Labour. On the same day, Desmond accused ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', (with which he was a joint venture partner in the West Ferry newspaper printing plant) then considering accepting a takeover by the German [[Axel Springer AG|Axel Springer]] group, of giving in to [[Nazism|Nazis]].{{cite news |url= http://media.guardian.co.uk/site/story/0,14173,1200881,00.html | title= Desmond taunts Telegraph in 'Nazi' tirade |work=The Guardian |date=22 April 2004 |location=London |first=Chris |last=Tryhorn |accessdate=22 May 2010}} Desmond reportedly harangued ''The Daily Telegraph''{{'s}} chief executive and associates in faux German at a business meeting and imitated [[Adolf Hitler]]. This incident was described as a form of [[institutionalised racism]] prevalent among newspaper proprietors.{{cite book|author1=Richard Keeble|author2=Ian Reeves|title=The Newspapers Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DvJTBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA83|date=21 August 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-50077-0|pages=83–84}} Previously, in August 2001, the [[National Union of Journalists]]' chapel at the ''[[Express & Star]]'' also condemned Desmond for the newspaper's "hysterical and racist" campaign against [[asylum seekers]]; this campaign was also criticised by [[Yasmin Alibhai-Brown]], writing for ''[[The Independent]]'' in June 2002.{{cite news|last1=Alibhai-Brown|first1=Yasmin|authorlink1=Yasmin Alibhai-Brown|title=I can take Mr Desmond's porn but not his racism|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/yasmin-alibhai-brown/i-can-take-mr-desmonds-porn-but-not-his-racism-178897.html|accessdate=1 April 2016|work=The Independent|date=2 June 2002}} In August 2005, the former executive editor of the ''Daily Express'' [[Ted Young (journalist)|Ted Young]] made an out-of-court settlement with Desmond's company ahead of an industrial tribunal. This related to an incident with Desmond in the newsroom in September 2004, during which Desmond was said to have hit the journalist.Chris Tryhorn [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/aug/24/pressandpublishing.dailyexpress "Express settles with former executive"], ''The Guardian'', 24 August 2005 Desmond has repeatedly denied the claims.Chris Tryhorn [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/aug/23/dailyexpress.pressandpublishing "Desmond punched me, claims former Express man"], ''The Guardian'', 23 August 2005MThe Guardian, 15 June 2015 https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/jun/19/richard-desmond-interview-hate-to-admit-never-hit-anyone Desmond is often referred to as "Richard 'Dirty' Desmond"{{cite news|title=Richard 'dirty' Desmond: A Humbuggery Special|url=http://www.private-eye.co.uk/sections.php?section_link=street_of_shame&issue=1323&article=619|deadurl=no|accessdate=1 April 2016|work=Private Eye|issue=1323|date=18 September 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130202075158/http://www.private-eye.co.uk/sections.php?section_link=street_of_shame&issue=1323&article=619|archivedate=2 February 2013}} or "Dirty Des"{{cite news|title=Richard Desmond: 'I've got so much money it's ridiculous'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/richard-desmond-ive-got-so-much-money-its-ridiculous-2006112.html|accessdate=1 April 2016|work=The Independent|date=20 June 2010}} in the ''[[Private Eye]]'' magazine due to his company [[Northern & Shell]] formerly owning a number of pornographic magazines and television channels. Desmond was apparently "wounded" by references to himself as a pornographer. In an interview with [[BBC Breakfast]] in 2015, Desmond was referred to as Digi Des due to his investments in digital media. A headline in the ''[[Evening Standard]]'' in 2000 said "Porn Publisher to Buy Express" in reference to Desmond. In a 2002 interview for ''[[BBC Newsnight]]'' with [[Jeremy Paxman]], [[Tony Blair]] was asked if it were appropriate to accept a controversial £100,000 donation from Desmond due to Desmond's links with the pornography industry,{{cite news|title='Soft-porn' donation defended by Blair|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/1991084.stm|accessdate=1 April 2016|work=BBC News Online|date=17 May 2002}} to which Blair replied "if someone is fit and proper to own one of the major national newspaper groups in the country then there is no reason why we would not accept donations from them".{{cite news|last1=Hogson|first1=Jessica|title=Desmond's good enough for me, says Blair|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/may/16/bbc.dailyexpress|accessdate=1 April 2016|work=The Guardian|date=16 May 2002}} Desmond has emphasised that his material has been available through [[WHSmith]] and [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]], saying that: "If it was pornography you would end up in prison because pornography is illegal". In 2008, Northern & Shell reported a turnover of £483.9 million.[http://www.northernandshell.co.uk/ir/2008_accounts.php Financial Results 2008] Northern & Shell announcement ==Libel case== Litigation began at the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] on 6 July 2009 over claims in journalist [[Tom Bower]]'s joint biography of [[Conrad Black]] and [[Barbara Amiel]], ''[[Conrad and Lady Black: Dancing on the Edge]]'', that Desmond had made a "humiliating climbdown" over an ''Express'' story at the end of 2002 on the state of Lord Black's finances, which it was alleged Desmond had ordered to be written. This claim of a weakening of Desmond's "super-tough" reputation as a businessman was viewed as defamation by Desmond. Bower denied libel on the grounds of the story being "substantially true".James Robinson [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jul/07/richard-desmond-tom-bower "Tom Bower book damaged Richard Desmond's 'super-tough' reputation, court hears",] ''The Guardian'', 7 July 2009 The following day, the presiding judge [[David Eady|The Hon. Mr Justice Eady]], discharged the jury as "fundamental" evidence and legal submissions had emerged.Alex Spence [http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/law/article6657094.ece "Jury discharged in Richard Desmond libel case",] ''The Times'', 7 July 2009 The new jury later found in favour of Bower.Patrick Foster [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article6725500.ece "Richard Desmond loses libel case with Tom Bower over Conrad Black claims"], ''The Times'', 24 July 2009 A biography of Desmond, ''Rough Trader'', was written by Bower and printed in 2006, but still awaits publication.{{cite news|author=Tom Bower|publisher=The Observer|date=26 July 2009|title=My week: Tom Bower|accessdate=6 June 2013|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jul/26/tom-bower-diary-richard-desmond|location=London}}{{cite web | title= Tom Bower to speak to NUJ after being barred from Express offices |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2015/apr/13/tom-bower-to-speak-to-nuj-after-being-barred-from-express-offices | last= Greenslade| first= Roy| date= 13 April 2015 | website= The Guardian | accessdate= 20 April 2015}} ==Developments since 2010== In July 2010, Desmond bought the UK terrestrial-television channel [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]], which was losing money, from the German group [[RTL Television|RTL]], for £103.5 million.{{cite press release | publisher = RTL Group | date = 23 July 2010 | title = RTL Group sells UK broadcaster Five | url = http://www.rtlgroup.com/www/htm/home_news.aspx?ID=C57D4206AF294A979A24C3EE4270E175 | accessdate = 24 July 2010 }}{{Cite news | title = Richard Desmond promises Channel Five 'investment, drive and leadership' | work = The Guardian | date = 23 July 2010 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jul/23/richard-desmond-channel-five1 | accessdate = 24 July 2010 | location=London | first=James | last=Robinson }}{{Cite news | title = UK: Media tycoon Desmond seals deal for Five | work = The Spy Report | publisher = Media Spy | date = 24 July 2010 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2010/07/24/uk-media-tycoon-desmond-seals-deal-for-five/ | accessdate = 24 July 2010 }} "Never before", wrote Tom Bower in ''[[The Guardian]]'' at the time, "has a government regulator (Ofcom) lowered the threshold for the suitability of the prospective owner of a TV channel enough for someone like Desmond to control a potentially lucrative franchise."Tom Bower [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/jul/24/richard-desmond-porn-kings-coup "Richard Desmond: the porn king's coup"], ''The Guardian'', 24 July 2010 The new owner immediately proceeded to cut costs, starting with the dismissal of seven of Channel 5's nine directors, beginning a drive to eliminate "£20m of yearly expenses". The stated plan included the dismissal of up to 80 of the network's 300 employees.[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/aug/12/bloodbath-five-richard-desmond "Bloodbath on Five as Richard Desmond clears out seven directors"] ''The Guardian'', 12 August 2010 In the year before Desmond acquired Channel 5 it had made a total loss of €41m (£37m), or a €9m loss at an operating level under its previous owner. Despite specific cost cutting, Desmond made significant investments in Channel 5 content, significantly increasing the programming budget. In the first full year of Desmond’s ownership of Channel 5, the broadcaster saw a 28% surge in revenue - the biggest TV advertising haul in the broadcaster's 14-year history - "thanks to factors including the arrival of Big Brother and the return of a major media buying contract with Aegis".The Guardian, 18 December 2011 https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/dec/18/channel-5-ad-revenues-soar He sold Channel 5 to Viacom for £463m in May 2014.{{cite news |last=Sweney |first=Mark |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/may/01/viacom-purchase-channel-5-richard-desmond |title= Viacom confirms purchase of Channel 5 from Richard Desmond for £450m |work=The Guardian |location= London |date=1 May 2014 |accessdate=12 July 2014}} By December 2010, the privately owned publishing venture employed more than 2,000 people internationally, according to Desmond. Northern & Shell's business interests in pornography finally ended in April 2016 when the Portland Television subsidiary, which broadcasts Television X and the Red Hot channels, was sold for under £1 million in a management buyout. ==Charity work and political activity== In 2003, Desmond and [[Roger Daltrey]] formed the [[RD Crusaders]], a rock group featuring Desmond on drums, to raise money for charitable causes. Since its inception, the group has raised around £14 million via a series of fundraising concerts for charities including Marie Curie, the Teenage Cancer Trust, Norwood Child Care and the Evelina Children's Hospital. As well as Daltrey and Desmond, the line-up occasionally includes [[Robert Plant]], [[Lulu (singer)|Lulu]], [[Steve Harley]], guitarists [[Russ Ballard]] (of [[Argent (band)|Argent]]) and [[Rick Wills]] (of [[Foreigner (band)|Foreigner]] and [[Bad Company]]), keyboardist [[Steve Smith (musician)|Steve Smith]] and organist [[Zoot Money]]. Desmond, an active supporter of children's charities, became president of [[Norwood (charity)|Norwood]] in 2006. Norwood is a leading UK Jewish charity, supporting vulnerable children, families and people with learning disabilities. He also ensured the attachment of his name to a children's centre at [[Moorfields Eye Hospital]], by contributing £2.5m to the £15m project.''Camden New Journal'', 8 February 2007 The centre is the world's largest specialist paediatric eye clinic, a centre treating more than 25,000 children a year.[http://www.moorfields.nhs.uk/aboutus/thericharddesmondchildrenseyecentre "The Richard Desmond Children's Eye Centre"]. Moorfields Eye Hospital. 25 February 2009. The centre was officially inaugurated in 2007 by [[Queen Elizabeth II]]. In December 2014, during the run up the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], Desmond was reported to have agreed to donate £300,000 to the [[UK Independence Party]].{{cite news |last1=Kleinman |first1=Mark |title=Express Owner Desmond Hands £300k To UKIP |url= http://news.sky.com/story/1390791/express-owner-desmond-hands-300k-to-ukip |date=12 December 2014 |accessdate=18 December 2014 |work=Sky News}} There was speculation at the time that a further donation could follow, and in April 2015 it was announced that he had given an additional £1 million to the party.{{cite news |title= Express owner Richard Desmond gives UKIP £1m |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2015-32340976| accessdate=16 April 2015 |date= 16 April 2015 |work= BBC News}} ==The Health Lottery== Desmond's company, [[Northern and Shell]], launched the [[Health Lottery]] in October 2011 of which around 20% of turnover goes to charity. The grants, distributed by the People's Health Trust (PHT), help many good causes and the elderly in local communities across the UK. By March 2018, [[The Health Lottery]] has raised nearly £100m for charities around the [[United Kingdom]] .{{cite news|last=Benjamin|first=Alsion|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2011/oct/19/health-lottery-good-news-charities|title=Is the health lottery good news for charities? |work=The Guardian|date=19 October 2011|accessdate=12 November 2017}} It supports local health causes throughout England, Scotland and Wales. The Health Lottery was to return 20.34p per £1 lottery ticket to good causes, which was compared unfavourably with the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]] donating 28p per £1 ticket. Sir [[Stephen Bubb]], then Chief Executive of the [[Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations]], accused Desmond of "profiteering on the back of charities".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15070628|title=Media group launches commercial lottery|publisher=BBC News|date=27 September 2011|accessdate=12 November 2017}} However, The Health Lottery's public accounts confirm that, as of 2017, the company had not made a profit since inception. The debate concluded that the much-needed changes to the prize limits of these lotteries - to £1m - would receive widespread support - not just from the Government benches but from the entire House - if they were to be made by the [[Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport]]. In an article in the [[Financial Times]] on 12 November, Desmond announced his intention to bid for the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]] license when it comes up for renewal in 2019.https://www.ft.com/content/1946797c-c4ac-11e7-a1d2-6786f39ef675 ==Personal life== Desmond and Janet Robertson were married for 27 years;{{cite news |author= Summerskill, Ben |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/sep/01/pressandpublishing.comment |title=Profile: Richard Desmond |work=The Observer |accessdate=20 September 2013 |location=London |date=2 September 2002}} the couple have a son, Robert. In October 2010,{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2010/oct/06/richard-desmond-divorce |work=The Guardian |location=London |title=No headlines for Desmond divorce |first=Roy |last=Greenslade |date=6 October 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2010}} Janet filed for divorce on the grounds of his "unreasonable behaviour" and was granted a [[decree nisi]] from the court.{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/desmond-and-wife-divorce-2098816.html |work=The Independent |location=London |title=Desmond and wife divorce |first=Jan |last=Colley |date=6 October 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2010}} He married Joy Canfield, a former manager for British Airways, in 2012.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/2915b0b8-0f67-11e5-897e-00144feabdc0.html|title=Lunch with the FT: Richard Desmond|author=Henry Mance|date=12 June 2015|work=The Financial Times|accessdate=22 January 2016}} The couple have two children; daughter Angel Millie (born 2011) and a son, Valentine (born 2015).{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/jun/19/richard-desmond-interview-hate-to-admit-never-hit-anyone|title=Richard Desmond: 'I hate to admit this, but I've never actually hit anyone'|author=Decca Aitkenhead|date=19 June 2015|work=The Guardian|accessdate=22 January 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.penguin.co.uk/authors/richard-desmond/1076884/|title=Penguin authors - Richard Desmond|publisher=[[Penguin Books]]|accessdate=22 January 2016}} The tycoon's autobiography, ''The Real Deal: The Autobiography of Britain's Most Controversial Media Mogul'', was published in June 2015 by [[Random House]].{{cite news |last=Greenslade |first=Roy |title=Tom Bower to speak to NUJ after being barred from Express offices |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2015/apr/13/tom-bower-to-speak-to-nuj-after-being-barred-from-express-offices |work=The Guardian |location= London |date=13 April 2015 |accessdate=9 June 2015}} It was ghost-written by ''Sunday Express'' editor Martin Townsend.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2014/oct/08/richard-desmond-nationalunionofjournalists|title=NUJ to Richard Desmond: sell Express Newspapers to someone who cares|last=Greenslade|first=Roy|date=8 October 2014|work=The Guardian|accessdate=8 June 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/06/19/richard-desmond-autobiography-review-daily-express_n_7621644.html|title=Richard Desmond's Autobiography Gets Five Stars In The Daily Express - His Own Newspaper|last=Harris|first=Sarah Ann|work=The Huffington Post|date=19 June 2015|accessdate=24 June 2015}} He also provided his voice for the audiobook version. The autobiography received a five-star review in the Desmond-owned ''Daily Express''.Aitkenhead, Decca (19 June 2015). [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/jun/19/richard-desmond-interview-hate-to-admit-never-hit-anyone "Richard Desmond: 'I hate to admit this, but I've never actually hit anyone'"]. with Sophie Walker | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xgfRQ8gVsVc "''Sandi Toksvig's Women's Equality Party name Sophie Walker as leader''"] via YouTube{{cite AV media | people= Sophie Walker | date= 22 July 2015 |accessdate= 21 September 2015 | title= Sandi Toksvig's Women's Equality Party name Sophie Walker as leader | medium= [[YouTube]] | publisher= [[Press Association]] | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xgfRQ8gVsVc }} }} }} '''Sophie Walker''' (born 27 May 1971{{cite web |title= Walker, Sophie |url= http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/no2013001085.html |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date= 21 September 2015 |quote= data view screen (b. 5-27-1971) }}{{cite news | last = Beaty | first = Zoe | title = Just who are the Women’s Equality Party and what do they stand for? | url = http://www.stylist.co.uk/life/who-are-the-womens-equality-party-and-what-do-they-stand-for-policies-pay-parenting-education | work = [[Stylist (magazine)|Stylist]] | publisher = Shortlist Media | date = March 2016 }}) is the Leader of the [[Women's Equality Party]] (WE) in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite news | last = Cohen | first = Claire | title = Watch out Cameron: Meet the leader of Britain's first feminist political party | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/womens-politics/11753983/Womens-Equality-Party-Meet-politics-new-chief-feminist-leading-it.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | publisher = [[Telegraph Media Group]] | date = 22 July 2015 | access-date = 21 September 2015 }}{{cite news | last = Ridley | first = Louise | title = Women's Equality Party leader Sophie Walker wants to end culture of "white men in suits" | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/09/08/womens-equality-party-sophie-walker_n_8101762.html | work = [[The Huffington Post]] | publisher = The Huffington Post Media Group | date = 8 September 2015 | access-date = 21 September 2015 }} She was appointed as inaugural leader by the steering committee and was the unanimous choice; from 2017 the leadership will be decided by elections.{{cite news | last = Cocozza | first = Paula | title = Women's Equality party founders: 'It needed doing. So we said, "Let's do it"' | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/28/womens-equality-party-founders-it-needed-doing-so-we-said-lets-do-it-sandi-toksvig | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 28 August 2015 | access-date = 21 September 2015 }} Walker was also the party candidate in the [[London mayoral election, 2016|2016 London mayoral election]].{{cite web|author=Charlie Cooper, Katie Forster |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/womens-equality-party-350000-votes-george-galloway-london-council-elections-a7018451.html |title=Women's Equality Party gets more than 350,000 votes and beats George Galloway in London |publisher=The Independent |date=7 May 2016 |accessdate=1 July 2016}} == Early life == Walker was born on 27 May 1971, the daughter of Lesley and David Walker.{{cite web | title = Sophie Walker | url = http://www.womensequality.org.uk/leader_sophie_walker | publisher = [[Women's Equality Party]] | access-date = 18 March 2017 }} She was born in [[Blackpool]], in [[England]], but grew up in [[Glasgow]], in [[Scotland]].{{cite news | last = Freeman | first = Sarah | title = Women’s Equality Party leader Sophie Walker: Why I can beat Philip Davies in Shipley | url = http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/analysis/women-s-equality-party-leader-sophie-walker-why-i-can-beat-philip-davies-in-shipley-1-8516038 | work = [[The Yorkshire Post]] | date = 28 April 2017 | access-date = 8 August 2017}} She attended university in England, studying English and French at the [[University of Reading]].{{cite web | last = Student services | title = Alumni lecture series: Sophie Walker, Women’s Equality Party | url = https://blogs.reading.ac.uk/student-services-news/2017/02/03/alumni-lecture-series-sophie-walker-womens-equality-party/ | publisher = [[University of Reading]] | date = 3 February 2017 | access-date = 7 August 2017}} Walker then took a postgraduate diploma in newspaper journalism at [[City, University of London|City University]], in [[London]].{{cite web | last = Walker | first = Sophie | title = Sophie Walker | url = https://uk.linkedin.com/in/sophie-walker-2117a847 | website = uk.linkedin.com | publisher = [[LinkedIn]] | access-date = 7 August 2017}} == Journalist == Walker's early career was in journalism, working as a reporter and then as an editor at the [[Reuters]] news agency. She covered the fields of finance, business and trade, plus politics. She reported from London, Paris and Washington and from Iraq, Afghanistan and Pakistan. == Women's Equality Party == As interim party leader, Walker launched the policy manifesto of the Women's Equality Party (WE) at [[Conway Hall]], 20 October 2015.{{cite web | title = Women's Equality Party announces first policies and campaigns | url = http://www.womensequality.org.uk/policy_launch_announcement | publisher = [[Women's Equality Party]] | date = 20 October 2015 | accessdate = 21 October 2015 }}{{cite news | last = Minter | first = Harriet | title = The Women's Equality Party launch is not a moment too soon | url = https://www.theguardian.com/women-in-leadership/2015/oct/21/the-womens-equality-party-launch-is-not-a-moment-too-soon | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 21 October 2015 | accessdate = 21 October 2015 }} Walker had previously told [[BBC Radio Wales]] ''[[BBC Radio Wales#Presenters|Sunday Supplement]]'' programme that the party would be taking a [[Nonpartisanism|non-partisan]] approach to elections, "We will be undertaking consultations with our members and deciding which seats to target."{{cite news | last = Staff writer | title = Women's Equality Party to field candidates in assembly elections | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-politics-33664219 | work = [[BBC news]]: Wales politics | publisher = BBC | date = 25 July 2015 | access-date = 22 September 2015 }} Walker was elected party leader in March 2018 with over 90% of the vote.{{cite web |title= Declaration of result: Women's Equality Party Leadership Election | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180308141643/https://d3n8a8pro7vhmx.cloudfront.net/womensequality/pages/4959/attachments/original/1520460695/results.pdf?1520460695 | archive-date = 8 March 2018 |url= https://d3n8a8pro7vhmx.cloudfront.net/womensequality/pages/4959/attachments/original/1520460695/results.pdf?1520460695 | website = uk-engage.org | publisher = UK Engage | access-date = 8 March 2018}} The term of office is five years and is due to run until 2023.{{cite web |title= Role description: Leader of the Women's Equality Party |url= https://files.ukevote.uk/wep/role_description__we_party_leader_18_12_17.pdf | website = pre.ukevote.uk/we | publisher = Election portal for the Women's Equality Party Leadership Election | access-date = 8 March 2018}} === London mayoral election, 2016 === Walker stood for election in the [[London mayoral election, 2016|London mayoral election]] held on 5 May 2016.{{cite news|last1=Lo Dico|first1=Joy|title=Sophie Walker: London is the worst place to live in the UK if you’re a woman|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/london-life/sophie-walker-london-is-the-worst-place-to-live-in-the-uk-if-you-re-a-woman-a3173071.html|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|accessdate=10 April 2016|date=6 February 2016}}{{cite web | title = Sophie Walker: the power of 4 million | url = http://www.womensequality.org.uk/sophie_for_london | publisher = [[Women's Equality Party]] | date = 2016 | accessdate = 10 April 2016 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161226121356/http://www.womensequality.org.uk/sophie_for_london/ | archivedate = 26 December 2016 | df = dmy-all }} She came sixth, with 53,055 votes (2% of the vote). === UK general election, 2017 === Walker stood in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 general election]] in [[Shipley (UK Parliament constituency)|Shipley]], against the sitting [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MP [[Philip Davies]], an anti-political correctness and men's rights campaigner.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39683982|title=General election 2017: Women's Equality Party leader to challenge MP Philip Davies|work=BBC News|date=23 April 2017|accessdate=23 April 2017}} She received 1,040 votes (1.9%) and finished fourth out of four candidates.{{cite news|last=Grant|first=Katie|url=https://inews.co.uk/essentials/news/politics/feminists-devastated-philip-davies-re-elected-shipley-seat/|title=Feminists 'devastated' Philip Davies re-elected to Shipley seat|date=9 June 2017|work=[[i (newspaper)|i news]]}} Three months later the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] announced they would be targeting Shipley at the next election and their candidate would be selected from an [[all-women shortlist]],{{cite news | last = Griffiths | first = Kathie | title = Shipley and Pudsey on leaked list of Conservative seats being targeted by Labour | url = https://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/15555072.Shipley_and_Pudsey_to_choose_Labour_candidates___39_before_Christmas__39_/ | work = [[Telegraph and Argus]] | location = [[Bradford]], West Yorkshire | date = 25 September 2017 | access-date = 24 September 2018}} [[Jo Pike]] was chosen in December the same year.{{cite web| last = Edwards | first = Peter | title = Labour picks child poverty expert to unseat Tory Brexiteer Philip Davies | url = https://labourlist.org/2017/12/labour-picks-child-poverty-expert-to-unseat-tory-brexiteer-philip-davies/ | website = labourlist.org | publisher = [[LabourList]] | date = 11 December 2017 | access-date = 24 September 2018}} == Family life == Walker is married to Christopher Naylor, the chief executive officer of [[Barking and Dagenham London Borough Council|Barking and Dagenham council]]. They live in [[London]] and have one daughter.{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/795701/Sophie-Walker-Womens-Equality-Party-leader-Philip-Davies-general-election|title=Who is Sophie Walker? Women’s Equality Party challenges Philip Davies in general election|first=Reiss|last=Smith|date=24 April 2017|publisher=}} Grace, Walker's daughter from a previous marriage has [[Asperger syndrome|Asperger's syndrome]] and Walker wrote a blog to give her daughter's life a voice.{{cite web | last = Walker | first = Sophie | title = Grace Under Pressure | url = http://courage-is.blogspot.co.uk/ | website = courage-is | publisher = Sophie Walker via [[Blogger (service)|Blogger]] }} This was published as the book ''Grace Under Pressure''.{{cite book | last = Walker | first = Sophie | title = Grace under pressure: going the distance as an Asperger's mum | publisher = [[Little, Brown Book Group|Hachette Digital]] | location = London | year = 2012 | isbn = 9781405516082 }} Walker has accepted an advocacy role with the [[National Autistic Society]]. == Media appearances == Walker has appeared on a number of media broadcasts within the UK including a panel discussion on free speech and equality with [[Jordan Peterson]] and [[Michael Fabricant]] for ''[[The Wright Stuff]]'' in which she stated, "I think the difference between Jordan and me is that we look at evidence and we lean towards different theories. So, Jordan's theory is very much evolutionary, that there are [[Gender essentialism|inherent differences in men and women]], mine is very much more [[Social construction of gender|social role theory]], if you like, that men and women are taking on different roles due to the expectations that society puts on them."{{cite AV media | people = [[Matthew Wright (television presenter)|Matthew Wright]] (presenter), [[Jordan Peterson]] (guest), Sophie Walker (guest) and [[Michael Fabricant]] (guest) | access-date= 18 May 2018 | date = 16 May 2018 | title= Jordan Peterson discusses whether men and women can ever be equal | medium= Television | series = [[The Wright Stuff]] | publisher= [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] via [[YouTube]] | minutes = 1.40 | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iy4vq8RdPGU}} == Publications == ;Books * {{cite book | last = Walker | first = Sophie | title = Grace under pressure: going the distance as an Asperger's mum | publisher = [[Little, Brown Book Group|Hachette Digital]] | location = London | year = 2012 | isbn = 9781405516082 }} ;Articles * {{cite news | last = Walker | first = Sophie | title = European farmers feel Russian sanctions bite | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/08/08/ukraine-crisis-sanctions-food-idUKL6N0QE30020140808 | publisher = Reuters | location = London | date = 8 August 2014 }} * {{cite news | last = Walker | first = Sophie | title = Our party’s going to reclaim women’s equality: help us make it happen | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/jul/24/womens-equality-party-make-it-happen | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 24 July 2015 }} ;Broadcast Media * {{cite AV media | people= Sophie Walker | date= 19 August 2015 |accessdate= 21 September 2015 | title= Our interview with Sophie Walker | medium= [[YouTube]] | publisher= www.thefemalelead.com | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9LCeHS0rfFw }} * In 2017, having led them to the final with two victories, Walker captained a team of celebrity former students from Reading University in ''[[University Challenge|Christmas University Challenge]]'' that was the first in the 55-year history of the quiz to fail to get a single question right. {{cite news|last1=Smyth|first1=Chris|title=Universally challenged: Reading alumni team gets zero|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/universally-challenged-reading-alumni-team-gets-zero-tqtktt932|accessdate=8 January 2018|work=The Times|date=8 January 2018}} == References ==
